thread.title: Oil turns lower as gasoline futures drop nearly 5%
thread.title_full: Oil turns lower as gasoline futures drop nearly 5% - MarketWatch

author: Myra P. Saefong   and   Eric Yep
title: Oil turns lower as gasoline futures drop nearly 5%
text:
Oil futures turned lower Wednesday despite a weekly decline in U.S. crude inventories, dragged down by a nearly 5% drop in gasoline futures, which were pressured by the restart of a key refinery and an unexpected increase in domestic stockpiles.
Investors also remained cautious amid volatile financial markets and continued uncertainty over China’s growth outlook, but oil had managed to find some support earlier Wednesday from China’s recent easing measures .
October West Texas Intermediate crude CLV5, -0.69% shed 18 cents, or 0.5%, to $39.13 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange, after trading as high as $39.86. October Brent crude LCOV5, +0.14% on London’s ICE Futures exchange fell 7 cents, or 0.2%, to $43.14 a barrel.
See slideshow: 6 important things to know about cheap oil
Early Wednesday, the U.S. Energy Information Administration reported that crude stockpiles fell 5.5 million barrels for the week ended Aug. 21. Analysts polled by Platts had forecast a rise of 1.9 million barrels, but the American Petroleum Institute Tuesday said supplies dropped 7.3 million barrels, according to sources.
“It seems as though the market has been a few days ahead of the headlines, as data seems to be priced in to the market already,” said John Macaluso, an analyst at Tyche Capital Advisors. “Despite a large draw in oil inventories, production has remained flat at [the futures delivery hub of] Cushing Okla.”
A midday correction is “probable,” but “the low’s have yet to be tested and [we] expect further weakness through the week,” he said.
Gasoline supplies, meanwhile, rose by 1.7 million barrels and distillate stockpiles climbed 1.4 million barrels last week, according to the EIA. Analysts surveyed by Platts were looking for a decline of 1.4 million barrels for gasoline supplies and an increase of 700,000 barrels for distillates, which include heating oil.
September heating oil RBU5, -4.80% fell 1.2 cents, or 0.9%, to $1.383 a gallon on Nymex, while September gasoline RBU5, -4.80% dropped 5.9 cents, or 4.8%, to $1.369 a gallon.
Adding pressure to gasoline prices, BP BP, -0.05% said late Tuesday that it has restarted a large crude distillation unit at its Whiting, Ind., refinery that had been shut down since Aug. 8 for repair work and that the restart is gradually increasing the refinery’s fuel production.
Read: $2 gas? It’s already happening in 12 states
Also on Nymex, natural gas for September delivery NGU15, +0.26% traded at $2.693 per million British thermal units, up less than a cent. On Thursday, the EIA will issue weekly supply data and the September contract will expire.
Sara Sjolin contributed to this report.
